plants.name: Rosa spp.
plants.description: Roses are hardy shrubs known for their beautifully layered and fragrant flowers. Many cultivars and wild species bloom in early to mid summer, producing flowers ranging from white to deep red and pink.
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide, especially Europe, North America, and Asia
plants.funFact: Roses have been symbols of love and beauty for thousands of years and have over 300 species worldwide.

plants.name: Lupinus polyphyllus
plants.description: Lupines are tall, spiky flowers with dense clusters that bloom profusely in summer. They often grow in wild meadows and garden settings, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies.
plants.location: North America and Europe (temperate to subalpine zones)
plants.funFact: Lupines enrich the soil with nitrogen thanks to their symbiotic relationship with nitrogen-fixing bacteria.

plants.name: Tibouchina urvilleana
plants.description: An evergreen shrub native to Brazil known for striking, velvety purple flowers that bloom abundantly in warmer months.
plants.bloomingSeason: June to August (Southern Hemisphere winter months translating to July bloom in mild climates)
plants.location: Brazil and as ornamental plant in subtropical regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Tibouchina flowers close at night and reopen with the morning sun, a behavior known as nyctinasty.

plants.name: Nymphaea spp.
plants.description: Aquatic plants producing large, fragrant flowers that float on the pond's surface. Many species bloom in summer, creating colorful displays in freshwater habitats.
plants.funFact: Water lilies regulate their temperature and can keep their flowers warmer than the surrounding air to attract pollinators.
